body: LGTM
can you  configuration  report  to the police at env.json  are you right

I agree with the job submission control in service, this implementation could be a straightforward solution to work.
I have another idea about this, to be more friendly for users. If possible, Griffin service could get spark cluster resource information, to judge if we can submit the jobs. There might be some difficulties about authentication, resource scheduling, spark application queue management, which seems overloaded for Griffin service function. Anyhow, we can have a discuss first.

@yangtong0912 could you also change the title for this PR as "Job rate limit for scheduler".

Same as ticket GRIFFIN-220.

Thanks,
William

> @yangtong0912 could you also change the title for this PR as "Job rate limit for scheduler".
> 
> Same as ticket GRIFFIN-220.
> 
> Thanks,
> William



> @yangtong0912 could you also change the title for this PR as "Job rate limit for scheduler".
> 
> Same as ticket GRIFFIN-220.
>

Ok. No problem

hi
could you fix these conflicts first?

Thanks,
William

> I agree with the job submission control in service, this implementation could be a straightforward solution to work.
> I have another idea about this, to be more friendly for users. If possible, Griffin service could get spark cluster resource information, to judge if we can submit the jobs. There might be some difficulties about authentication, resource scheduling, spark application queue management, which seems overloaded for Griffin service function. Anyhow, we can have a discuss first.

Yes , that's a good idea. It's simple and straightforward. In terms of resources, I think there are two problems. The first is the spark cluster resources. As you said, it is necessary to judge whether jobs can be submitted in advance. This is for the spark cluster resources. The second resource is livy. Now the Griffin production server is actually a single point of Livy submission, Livy is batch processing at the same time, each task will have a thread to deal with, will also occupy the resources of the production server, so here should also add queue control, or submit to more servers, that is, multi-point submission.

can you env.json config monitoring mail  ??

> can you env.json config monitoring mail ??

No, my version used <user-param> to configure mail. I think it might be better to use dq.json configuration now.

> > can you env.json config monitoring mail ??
> 
> No, my version used to configure mail. I think it might be better to use dq.json configuration now.

How to configure email alerts
Is there an example?

> > > can you env.json config monitoring mail ??
> > 
> > 
> > No, my version used to configure mail. I think it might be better to use dq.json configuration now.
> 
> How to configure email alerts
> Is there an example?

You can modify dq.json according to the example of the official website, add the json field containing mail, and then parse the json field containing mail in the measure package.

hi fusonghe,

I think you can ask questions in dev mailing list, if your question is not related to this PR.

Send email to dev-subscribe@griffin.apache.org to subscribe 
and then you can discuss your question in dev@griffin.apache.org .

Thanks,
William

sure,  quartz format: [Seconds] [Minutes] [Hours] [Day of month] [Month] [Day of week] [Year(Optional)] and crontab format:[Minutes] [Hours] [Day of month] [Month] [Day of week] [Year]. Quartz has '?' which means you don't care about the value, but crontab don't have.

@guoyuepeng Thanks for your code review. I'm on vacation. And I'll finish this work next week.

@bhlx3lyx7 
Thank you for your advice. 
Yes, may systems have two or more execution engine inside ,and users can change the engine in different situation.
But If parallel execution is good than before, and works better in all situation, why should we still kept that execution engine?

What I have changed:
1. add one implementation of HiveMetaStoreService
2. add hive-jdbc dependency in service/pom.xml
3. changed postgre to mysql
4. add griffin server port (default 8080), default application.properties doesn't have this
        server.port = 8080
        spring.application.name=griffin_service

Build:
mvn clean install -DskipTests

Run:
java -jar service/target/service-0.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar
I have changed get connection code, and now using JDBC to retrieve Hive metadata is working on my local machine.

Thanks for cleaning up dependencies in pom.

the PR process is as below.

- Create ticket in griffin jira 
   https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/GRIFFIN/issues

- Submit your PR and titled it as GRIFFIN-{NUMBER} AS 
   https://github.com/apache/griffin/pull/486

Thanks for contributing.

William
LGTM
sure.

I have reviewed all changes.

Currently we have many env related settings, such as 
db
 - mysql
 - postgresql

auth
 - noauth
 - keytab

metadata
 - jdbc connect directly
 - hive
etc,.


Let us think how to uniformly handle modules to separate public simple deployment vs enterprise specific deployment.

Thanks,
William

hi Joohnnie,

Hi William,
I have rebased and please help to check.

Thanks
Johnnie
Thanks, Johnnie.

It seems that your configuration is based on the default configuration of spring boot, I think there is no problem with the content. 

But I'm not sure if giving an implementation like what you do or giving a guide in a document is better, cause If users want customized log, they may still need to make some changes in these files.

@whhe Thanks for your comments. 
The config is the default configuration from spring boot. The reason I put it to the code base because we can easily change the config based on our need. Otherwise, users even don't know what' the log library they used.
In addition to that, I removed some dependencies as they will cause the confliction in the log system.

Regarding the guild, log4j2 is an open-source library and has its official website.
User can refer to the website to customize the config.  
https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/index.html
